From Wiktionary, the free dictionary

English

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

From propose +‎ -er.

Pronunciation

[edit]
This entry needs pronunciation information. If you are familiar with the IPA or enPR then please add some!
  • Audio (US):(file)

Noun

[edit]

proposer (plural proposers)

  1. Agent noun of propose: someone who proposes; someone who makes a proposal.
    Synonym: proponent
    Antonyms: opponent, opposer, detractor

Translations

[edit]
Translations
  • Arabic: مُقْتَرِح (muqtariḥ)
  • French: proposant (fr), proposeur (fr)
  • Marathi: प्रस्तावक m (prastāvak)

See also

[edit]
  • adherent
  • advocate
  • backer
  • champion
  • exponent
  • supporter

Further reading

[edit]
  • “proposer”, in OneLook Dictionary Search.
  • “propose”, in Merriam-Webster Online Dictionary, Springfield, Mass.: Merriam-Webster, 1996–present.
  • “proposer”, in Collins English Dictionary.
  • “proposer”, in Wordnik.
  • proposer in WordReference English Collocations
  • “proponent” in Moby Thesaurus II, Grady Ward, 1996.
  • “proposer, proponent, supporter”, in Google Books Ngram Viewer.
  • “proposer, opposer”, in Google Books Ngram Viewer.

Anagrams

[edit]
  • Prospero, prospore

French

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

Inherited from Old French proposer, borrowed from Latin prōpōnere, altered based on French poser.

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /pʁɔ.po.ze/
  • Audio:(file)
  • Audio (France (Vosges)):(file)
  • Audio (France (Somain)):(file)
  • Rhymes: -e
  • Homophones: proposai, proposé, proposée, proposées, proposés, proposez

Verb

[edit]

proposer

  1. to propose, suggest
    on m'a proposé de tester des produits
    I've been asked to test the products
  2. to propose (offer)

1 The French gerund is usable only with the preposition en.
2 In less formal writing or speech, these tenses may be found to have been replaced in the following way:
past historic → present perfect
past anterior → pluperfect
imperfect subjunctive → present subjunctive
pluperfect subjunctive → past subjunctive

(Christopher Kendris [1995], Master the Basics: French, pp. 77, 78, 79, 81).

Further reading

[edit]
  • “proposer”, in Trésor de la langue française informatisé [Digitized Treasury of the French Language], 2012.

Norman

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

From Old French proposer, borrowed from Latin prōpōnō, prōpōnere, altered based on poser.

Verb

[edit]

proposer

  1. (Jersey) to propose

Old French

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

Borrowed from Latin prōpōnō, prōpōnere, from Latin prō- (“forth”) + pōnere (“place, put”), altered based on poser.

Verb

[edit]

proposer

  1. to propose (offer)
  2. to place on top of

Conjugation

[edit]

This verb conjugates as a first-group verb ending in -er. The forms that would normally end in *-ss, *-st are modified to s, st. Old French conjugation varies significantly by date and by region. The following conjugation should be treated as a guide.

    Conjugation of proposer (see also Appendix:Old French verbs)
simple compound
infinitive proposer avoir proposé
gerund en proposant gerund of avoir + past participle
present participle proposant
past participle proposé
person singular plural
first second third first second third
indicative jo tu il nos vos il
simple
tenses 		present propos proposes propose proposons proposez proposent
imperfect proposoie, proposeie, proposoe, proposeve proposoies, proposeies, proposoes, proposeves proposoit, proposeit, proposot, proposeve proposiiens, proposiens proposiiez, proposiez proposoient, proposeient, proposoent, proposevent
preterite proposai proposas proposa proposames proposastes proposerent

conditional proposeroie, proposereie proposeroies, proposereies proposeroit, proposereit proposeriiens, proposeriens proposeriiez, proposeriez proposeroient, proposereient

tenses 		present perfect present tense of avoir + past participle

Descendants

[edit]
  • Middle French: proposer
    • French: proposer
    • Norman: proposer
    • → Middle English: proposen
      • English: propose, propound
